titlestmt.title: SSSC 02: Wisahketchahk, the Partridges, and the Stone
titlestmt.author: Adam Sakewew

bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: Sacred Stories 02: Wisahketchahk, the Partridges, and the Stone

p.seg: kîtahtawê sipwêhtêw wîsahkêcâhk . Once upon a time Wisahketchahk set out.
kîtahtawê wâpamêw osk-âyîsisah wacistwanihk pihêsisah . Presently he saw some young partridges in a nest.

seg.gloss: “My little brothers, partridges, what is your name?”

seg.q:
âtah kiwîhinân ,
pihêwak
k-êtwêyin ; êkosi pikoh êy-isiyîhkâsoyâhk .
seg.gloss: “But you just did name us, when you said, ‘partridges’; that is the only name we have.”

p.seg:
namoya ! itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ;
kahkiyaw kêkway nîswayak isiyîhkâtêw . “No!” said Wisahketchahk; “Everything has two names.”

seg.gloss: “No, little brother! Take thought upon it;
you have some other name besides.”

p.seg:
êkosi awah ostêsimâs omis îtêw :
âta wiya mâna nikâwiy nôhtâwiy ,
okoskohiwêsîsak
kitisiyîhkâsonânaw , êkwah
pihêwak ; Thereupon the oldest of them said to him, “To be sure, my mother and father do say to us, ‘Little Startlers,’ we are called; and ‘Partridges’;

seg.gloss: we have two names.”

p.seg: isay ! nitakis ôki koskohiwêcik ! itêw , êh-mîsît ostikwâniyihk , êh-pîwêyimât ; “Bosh! Fine ones these are to startle anyone!” he said to them, [shitting on their heads] to show his contempt;
nam âwiyak ka-kî-sêkihâwâw ! itêw . “You will never scare anybody!” he told them.
êkosi nakatêw . With that he left them.
êkwah ôki pihêwak êh-kîwêcik , awên ôhi otawâsimisiwâwa ! Then, when those partridges came home, what had happened to their children!
kîh-mêyiwiyiwah ostikwâniyihk . [no translation]

tânihk om , nitawâsimisitik , k-ôh-isinâkosiyêk , êh-wîhcêkisiyêk ? itikwak ôkâwiyiwâwah ôhtâwiyiwâwah mîna . “Why is this, children, that you look like this [no translation]?” their mother and their father asked them.

seg.q:
wiy âna wîsahkêcâhk ê-kakwêcimikoyâhk ,
tânisi êsiyîhkâsoyêk , nisîmitik , pihêtik ? êh-itikoyâhk , êkâ ê-wîhtamôwâyâhk ,
âta kosâ kiwîhinân , êh-itâyâhk ,
namoya ; kahkiyaw kêkway nîsoyîhkâtêw , nitikonân .
seg.gloss: “Why, when that person Wisahketchahk asked us, ‘What is your name, little brothers, partridges?’ and we did not tell him, but said to him ‘but you have just spoken our name,’ then he said to us, ‘No; everything has two names.’

seg.q:
piyisk niwîhtamawâw ,
okoskohiwêsîsak nitisiyîhkâsonân , êh-itak ,
ntakis ôki koskohiwêcik , k-êtikoyâhk , êh-mîsît nistikwâninâhk .
seg.gloss: At last I told him, saying to him, ‘Little Startlers we are called,’ whereupon he said of us, ‘Fine ones these are to startle anyone,’ [no translation]
With that he was off and away, laughing.”
“Well, wife, come away.

seg.q:
mâka mina sîpîsis otihtahkih , êkotah ka-wawiyasihânaw ,
ntakis ôki sêkihiwêcik , k-êtât kitawâsimisinawa ; kanôhkawâtân .
seg.gloss: When he comes to the creek again, we shall make him a laughing-stock for saying to our children, ‘Fine ones these, to startle anyone.’ Let us attack him.”

p.seg: tâpwê pihêwah mâwihkâtêwak , êh-mâwacihitocik . Accordingly they appealed to the other partridges, and all assembled.
êkwah kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk sîpîsis ê-sakâyik . Then presently he came to the creek in the woods.
êkwah âyîtaw âyîtawakâm pihêwak apiwak êkotah , êh-kâsôcik . And there on both sides, on both banks sat the partridges in concealment.
êkwah wîsahkêcâhk otihtam sîpîsis . Then Wisahketchahk reached the creek.
wâsêkamiyiw . The water was bright and clear.

êkosi ê-wâpahtahk , mostoswayânah akwanahôw ; êkwah pahkêkin oskotâkay ; êkwah pahkêkin otâsah . When he came to it there, he had on a buffalo robe; and leather was his coat; of leather were his breeches.

êkwah omis îtwêw :
mahtih
- sôhki pîkiskwêw - Then he spoke as follows: “Come” and loudly he spoke -

seg.q:
iskêkânih osk-âyih astotin astwâtohk , osk-âyah ayôwinisah ,
awiyak âsiwakâmêohpîcih , kit-âyâw ôhih , itwêhk .
seg.gloss: “I have a feeling that a new hat has been put up as a prize, and new clothes, and it has been announced, ‘If anyone jumps to the far shore, he shall have these.’

p.seg: nistwâw nika-nômiskên ; êkotah nêwâw mwêhci nik-ohpîn , itwêw . Three times I shall stop short; then, the fourth time, I shall jump,” he said.
nitohtâk ôhi pihêwah ; mâka namoya wâpamêw . The partridges listened to him; but he did not see them.
êkwah kospohtêw . Then he walked back up the bank.
aciyaw nika-wêpikâtân , itwêw ; âcimostawêw tânisi êh-wîh-tôtahk . “For a short while I shall exercise my legs,” he said; he simply told them what he meant to do.
otakohpah ôtah ahêw ; tâpiskawêw . he put his blanket-robe here, like this; he put it round his neck.
sisonê sîpîsisihk naki-kwâskohtiw . at the bank of the creek he stopped with a jump. NEW PARAGRAPH
yôhah , nahpihcis nika-sâpopahâw , nôhtêpayiyânih , itwêw ; “Tut tut, I shall get my tobacco-pouch all wet, if I don't make it,” he said;

seg.gloss: “I'll throw it across.”

p.seg: namoya kanawâpamêw , ômisi êh-isiwêpinât ; he did not keep his eye on it as he flung it;
akâmihk pahkisiniyiwa . like this it fell somewhere on the other bank.
êh-wêpinât , pêyak pihêwa k-ohpahoyit . When he threw it, one of the partridges flew up.
yôho , mâna tâpwê nka-koskowihikoh ! itwêw . “Tut tut, really, he came very near startling me!” he said.

seg.gloss: “Now only three times more!”

p.seg: min âsay nôhcimihk itohtêw . Again he went away from the water.
namoya kiskêyihtam itêh wahpihcisah k-êsiwêpinât . He did not know the exact spot to which he had tossed his tobacco-pouch.
êkwah pê-wayacâwiw ; nakîw . Then he came with a running start; he stopped.
nîso ! êkwah piko nîswâw , itwêw . “Two! Now only twice more!” he said.
êkwah nîs ohpihâyiwah . Then two of them flew up.

seg.q: yôhoh , mânah nika-sêkihikohtayik ôkih pihêwak okoskohiwêsîsak !
seg.gloss: “Tut tut, they came mighty near scaring me, these partridges, these little startlers!”

p.seg: âsay mina sipwêhtêw . Again he went off.
âsay mina pê-môskîstam oma sîpîsis . Again he came running at that creek.

seg.gloss: “Three! Now this time I shall jump.

seg.q:
iskêkâniyah osk-âyah astwâtohk astotin ayôwinisah ,
awiyak âsiwâkâmê-ohpîcih nika-miyâw , itwêhk .
seg.gloss: Without doubt a new hat has been put up as a prize, and new clothes, with the statement, ‘If anyone jumps across the water, I shall give him these.’

p.seg: êkwah mâka niwîh-ohpîn , itwêw . But now I shall jump,” he said.

êkwah sipwêhtêw ; êkwah êkotê sâkowêw :
êkwah niwîh-ohpîn ; Then he was off; and then he shouted: “Now I am going to jump;

seg.gloss: I am going to take the new clothes;
I, I shall have them;
I am going to jump!

p.seg: namoya êkwah niwîh-nakîn ! itwêw ; This time I shan't stop!” he cried;
âcimostawêw ôhih kâ-kâsôhtâkot . he gave it all away to them who were hiding from him.
êkwah pê-wêyacâwiw , ê-pê-sâkowêt . Then he came with a running start; he came a-shouting.
mitoni kisiwâsiw pisisik . He kept himself in a high state of excitement.
timîw oma sîpîsis . [no translation]
om êh-ohpît âyîtawakâm pihêwah kâ-ohpiyit , êh-pitihkoyit . When he jumped, up went the partridges from both banks with a whirr.
sêkisiw ; tâwakâm pahkisin . He was scared; he fell into the middle of the water.

ôhi kâ-manâcihtât omaskisinah , otâsah kâ-tâpiskahk , kahkiyaw sâpopatâw , otakohpah . Those moccasins of his, which he treated with such care, his breeches, which he had round his neck, he got them all drenched, and his blanket-robe.
cê ! macastimwak kâ-koskowihicik , kâ-sâpopatâwak ntayôwinisah ! itwêw . “Bah! Those dirty dogs startled me and made me get my clothes all wet!” he cried.
êkwah pâsam . Then he dried them.

seg.gloss: “Ha, I shall have a smoke!

p.seg: kîh-pîhtwâyânih , êkoyikohk ta-pâstêwah ôhi nitayôwinisah , itwêw . When I have smoked, these clothes of mine will be dry,” he said.
êkwah ê-ntonawât wahpîhcisah , nama miskawêw . Then, when he looked for his tobacco-pouch, he could not find it.

seg.gloss: “Where can it be that I lost my tobacco-pouch?”

p.seg: ntonawêw nipîhk , êkwah êkâ ê-miskawât . He looked for it in the water, but he did not find it.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât êh-akociniyit . Then all at once he saw it lying in the water.

seg.gloss: “Bah! This nasty tobacco-pouch has been hiding from me!
I was getting sad for want of a smoke!”

p.seg: akohciniyiwah ; otinêw ; nama kêkway . It lay there in the water; he reached to take it; there was nothing.
piyisk omayikohk ; nama kêkway . At last as far as this; nothing.
âh , êh-tapasît awa nahpihcis ! itêyihtam ; “Oho, and so this tobacco-pouch of mine is running away!” he thought;

seg.gloss: “It has been away a long time, for all I could do.”

p.seg: êkwah omis êh-tôtahk , piyisk nahapiw . Then, when he reached like this, at last he was in a sitting position.
nêtê mohcihk kâskatâwahkinikêw ; nama kêkway . Way out he was scratching up gravel from the bed of the stream; nothing.

êwakw âwa nahpihcis ! itwêw ,
mahtih êkwah nik-ôtinâw , êh-itêyihtahk . “There is my tobacco-pouch!” he cried; “Now do let me take it,” he thought.
kisiwâsiw âsay . He was angry by this time.

êkwah omis êh-tôtahk , ôtah êh-akohcihk ôtah ,
nk-âti-omis-îtiskwêyin , êy-itêyihtahk , pôt ôhi ispimihk ôtah mistikohk kîh-akociniyiwah . Then, when he did like this, there where, by this time, he lay in the water, thinking, “I will turn my head like this when I reach,” why, there, up aloft in a tree there, hung that thing.

seg.gloss: “Bah! There is that nasty tobacco-pouch I kept losing till it made me miserable!
As if I hadn't been longing for a smoke!

p.seg: êcik âwah itah êy-akocihk ! itwêw ; And so, there it hangs!” he cried;
ncawâc namoy âwiyak , itwêw , êh-otinât , “Since you won't have it otherwise, be absent,” he said, taking it;

seg.gloss: “Since you won't have it otherwise, I'll teach you how to be of no use.”

p.seg: wêpinêw . He gave it a fling.
nama kêkwayah ôh otôspwâkana wahpîhcisah minah . Gone was his tobacco-pouch, and his pipe as well.
wêpinêw . He threw them away.
kîsopwêyiw . It was hot weather.
nam êskwah pâstêyiwah otayôwinisah . His garments were not yet dry.
nicawâc sipwêhtêw . So he needs went off without.
kîtahtawê sâpopêyiwa otakohpah ; kosikwatêyiwah . Now his blanket was drenched through; it was heavy.

osâm ê-kîsopwêyik , êh-pimohtêt , pôtih osâm êh-pwâwihât ôh ôtakohpah , ê-kisâstêyik , pôtih kâ-wâpamât asiniyah ê-misikitiyit . And as the weather was very hot, as he walked along, he could hardly carry that blanket-robe of his, in the hot sun, when there he saw a big stone.
tohtêw . He walked over there.

êw-otihtât ,
hâw , nisîm , itêw ôh âsiniyah ,
kimiyitin awa nitakohp , itêw . When he came up to it, “Now, brother,” he said to that stone, “I give you this blanket of mine,” he said to it.
akwanahêw . He put the robe on the stone.
kâh-akwanahât , ati-sipwêhtêw ; mosêskatêw . When he had covered it, he went away; he went naked.
êkwah namoya wâhyaw êh-ihtât , kâ-pê-nôkwaniyik ê-wîh-kimiwaniyik , êh-pê-kâh-kitôyit piyêsiwah . Then, when he had not gone far, there came signs of rain; as the Thunderers sounded their approach.

seg.gloss: “Tut tut, I shall be drenched!

p.seg:
nicawâc kâwih nka-nâtâw kâ-kîh-mêkiyân , itêyihtam ,
nitakohp . I shall have to get back the thing I gave away,” he thought, “my blanket.”
kîwêpahtâw ; takohtêw ; otinêw . He ran back; he came to the place; he took it.
npê-nâtâw awa nitakohp , itwêw . “I have come to get my blanket here;” he said.

yahah , mâka mîna nika-wiy-pimitisahok awa kâ-kîh-miyak nitakohpah ! itwêw , êh-itât ôhih asiniyah . “Dear me, but now this fellow to whom I had given my blanket will come and chase me!” he said, speaking of that stone.
ay-âpasâpiw . He kept looking behind him.
êkosi kîtahtawê kâ-waskawiyit ôh âsiniyah , piyê-tihtipiyit . And soon, there, that stone began to move and roll toward him.
môskîstâk , tâpiskôc ôma êh-tihtipipayiyit . It went for him, rolling along, like this.

yahah , omîhkawikîh awa ! itêw ;
isi cikâhtaw ! “Dear me, he runs fast, this fellow!” he said of it; “It's a close shave, this!”
piyisk kisiwâk ; wêyacâwiw . At last it was near; he ran hard.
kîsopwêyiw ; kîpah nayawapiw . It was hot weather; soon he was tired.
âmaciwêw ispatinâhk . He ran up a hill.

seg.q: mahtih êk ê-kîh-pêy-âmaciwêt awa kâ-watakamisit , nitakohpah ê-kîh-awihak !
seg.gloss: “Let's hope that he won't be able to come up the hill, this dangerous person to whom I lent my blanket!”

p.seg: êkwah tâpwê mîhkawikiyiwa . Truly, it went fast.
nicawâc tapasîw . There was nothing to do but flee.

êtây ê-sakâyik itâmôw .
mahtih kit-âtisin awa kâ-watakamisit ! êh-itwêt . He fled to a wooded place, “Let's hope that dangerous character will be blocked!” he said.
êkwah sakâw êw-otihtahk aw âsiniy , kâh-kawiskawêw ôhi mistikwah . But when that stone reached the wooded place, it knocked over one tree after another.
âsay wîsahkêcâhk sêkisiw ; êkwah wayacâwiw . By this time Wisahketchahk was thoroughly frightened; he ran with all his might.
osâm êk âwiyak ta-kîh-itâmoyân , kayâs nôhtâwiy ê-kî-nipit , itwêw ; “And there is no one I can flee to, for my father died long ago,” he said;
ta-kîh-nâtamawit nam âwiyak , itwêw . “There isn't anyone could help me,” he said.
paskwâhk itâmôw . He fled into the open country.
mitonih nayawapiw . He was very tired.
ncawâc kiyâm nka-nipahik , êh-itêyihtahk , kawipayihôw . “There is no escape; he will kill me, that's all,” he thought, and flung himself down.
ositihk mâhtakoskâk ôhih asiniyah . The stone came down on his foot and held him fast.
âstam-itah nawac , nisîm ! itêw . “Farther up this way, brother!” he said to it.
pêy-âhtapiyiwah oskâtihk ; êkwah mâhtakoskâk . It moved farther up, onto his leg; it held him fast with its weight.

seg.gloss: “Farther up this way, brother!”

p.seg:
namoya ! itik ;
kîspin itahk êpiyânih , nama wîhkâc nitâhtapin , itik . “No!” it answered him; “If I sit down anywhere, I never change my seat,” it answered him.

êkosi êkwah nama kih-pihkohôw , kahkiyaw kêkway pêmohtêyic êkotah , manicôsah ,
kakwê-pihkohin , nisîm ! êh-itât ,
namoya ! nikostâw ! êy-itikot . So now he could not get himself free, and whenever any creature, even a worm or a beetle, went by, “Try and get me free, little brother!” he would say to it, but “No! I am afraid of him!” it would answer him.

seg.gloss: “Little brother, please take pity on me!”

p.seg: namoya ! nikostâw osâm ! kîh-itâw ; “No! I fear him too much!” he was told;
pêyakwanohk kit-âpit , itah êpicih , itik nanâtohk ôhih kêkwah . “Let him stay where he is, when he takes his seat anywhere,” those different creatures said to him.
kîtahtawê pîskwah kinwês kâ-kitoyit ; êh-kitoyit , kâ-cîpipayiyit . Then at one time the mosquito hawk gave a long, repeated cry; when it cried, the stone moved with a jerk.
yôhôn , pakâhkam aw âsiniy kostêw êwakonih , itêyihtam ; “Hoho, plainly this stone fears this one creature,” he thought;

seg.gloss: “Little brother, come here!”

seg.q: hâh , nistêsê , êyâh , mâka minah wâ-tôtawiyan !
seg.gloss: “Hah, big brother, I wonder what you will be doing to me this time!”
“No, truly, little brother! Try to get me free;
this stone is killing me with its weight.

seg.q: kik-êsi-miyosiyan kik-êsîhitin , kîspin pahkwatinaci awa asiniy .
seg.gloss: I will make you beautiful, if you move this stone away.”
“Very well; but do not lie;

p.seg: nitaka nnôhtê-miyosin , nistêsê , itik pîskwah . I surely much want to be beautiful, big brother,” the mosquito hawk answered him.
êkotêw ohci pê-môskîstawêw ôh âsiniyah ; from there it came attacking that stone;
pwêkicitêw . [no translation].
pâscipayiw aw âsiniy . The stone split.
kêyâpic nama kîh-pihkohôw awa wîsahkêcâhk . Even yet Wisahketchahk could not get himself free.

seg.gloss: “Little brother, keep at it!
Do try to get me free!
I will make you handsome; I will deck you out.”
“Very well, big brother; I am very eager to be beautiful;

p.seg: osâm niwiyîpisin , itik . I am too drab of colour,” it answered him.
mitoni kisiwâk pwêkicitêw ôhî asiniyah . [no translation]
mitonih pîkopayiyiwa ; nanânis apiyiwa . The stone burst into many pieces; it lay here and there.
pihkohôw awa wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was free.

êkwah ,
âstam , nisîm ; mistahi kitatamihin ! Then, “Come here, little brother; you have greatly obliged me!”
âkwah wâpatoniskah , asiskiy êh-wâpiskâyik otinam wîsahkêcâhk ; Then Wisahketchahk took up some white clay, white earth;
êkwah awah pîskwah wâ-wâpamisôw , pâh-pahkih êh-wâpiskisit . then that mosquito-hawk looked at itself, and saw that it was streaked with white.

êkwah omis itêyihtam :
tâpwê nimiyosin ! itêyihtam . Then this it thought: “Surely I am beautiful!” it thought.

seg.gloss: “Come here, little brother.
Let me arrange your face as well;
too long is your beak.
“Come here! It ought to be only as long as this.”

p.seg: êhag , itik . “Very well,” it answered him.
êkwah omisi tôtawêw ; asânaskatinamwêw . Then he did like this to it; he bent the thing crooked for it.
êkwah sîsikoc otihtinêw , ôm ôtôniyiw omis êy-ispitamwât . And then suddenly he grabbed it and stretched out its mouth for it, like this.
êkwah pakwâtam awa pîskwah ê-misâyik oton . The mosquito-hawk hated having a big mouth.
êkoyikohk kahkiyaw . That is all.
